awd_titl_txt: Modeling Brain and Behavior to Uncover the Eye-Brain-Mind Link during Complex Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The project, based at the University of Colorado, will advance fundamental knowledge on learning from complex STEM texts. This is a critical skill for success in an increasingly information-driven world and workforce, but it is also an area where students consistently struggle. Scores on standardized assessments are stubbornly stagnant, troublesome achievement gaps remain, and the U.S. continues to lag behind its international peers. This is especially relevant to the reading of complex STEM content. The main idea of the project is that learning from text is fundamentally about the coordination of vision (the eye) with thought (the mind) in a manner constrained by the content (the text), the context (the task), and the individual (the learner). Thus, there is a need to understand how these factors interact in order to advance basic knowledge and to inform effective interventions. The team will study how brain and behavioral signals can be used to understand the reading process and associated learning outcomes in a manner that is sensitive to individual differences. Anticipated near-term broader impacts include the interdisciplinary training of students, especially those from groups underrepresented in STEM fields, community outreach, and promoting scientific reasoning skills relevant to multiple STEM areas. In the longer term, the results of the project will inform the design of future interventions that aim to make learning from text more efficient, engaging, and effective. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances the fundamental research literature on STEM learning.

The intellectual merit of the project is to gain fundamental knowledge on how the eye and brain dynamically coordinate to construct mental representations during complex learning from STEM texts. The project will address this goal by collecting eye movements, reading behaviors, noninvasive brain signals, and learning outcomes from high-school and college students in controlled lab settings and in school environments. It is expected that students will improve critical thinking and scientific reasoning skills by engaging with multiple texts on scientific research methods. The project will use behavioral (eye tracking and reading times) and non-invasive brain measures (high-density functional near-infrared spectroscopy and electroencephalography) to identify neurobehavioral markers of core processes involved in reading comprehension (e.g., focused attention vs. mind wandering, inference generation and elaboration) and the extent to which these measures can predict learning outcomes (comprehension, knowledge, and transfer) assessed immediately after learning and a week later. The project will also leverage advances in deep machine learning to build computational neurobehavioral models of the process and outcome variables in a manner that is sensitive to textual difficulty and to individual differences (e.g., prior knowledge, interest). Thus, the project will advance fundamental knowledge by integrating three research areas: theories of low-level reading processes and associated models of eye movements, models of higher-order STEM text comprehension including multiple document comprehension, and emerging research on the cognitive neuroscience of reading including co-registration with eye movements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview. The project advances fundamental knowledge on how the eye and brain dynamically coordinate to construct mental representations during complex learning from texts to improve critical thinking and scientific reasoning skills. The research uses behavioral (eye tracking and reading times) and non-invasive brain measures (high-density functional near-infrared spectroscopy [fNIRS] and electroencephalography [EEG]) to identify neurobehavioral markers of core comprehension processes (e.g.,  focused attention vs. mind wandering, inference generation and elaboration) and the extent to which these measures predict learning outcomes (comprehension, knowledge, and transfer) assessed during, immediately after, and at delay. We had two objectives:

  • Objective 1 focused on discovering brain and behavioral signals that index comprehension processes and outcomes while understanding the moderating role of individual differences and the reading context. 
  • Objective 2 focused on developing generalizable neurobehavioral computational models of core reading process and outcomes to enable real-time measurement and intervention.

 

We accomplished the following key research outcomes towards addressing our objectives. 

  • Large multimodal dataset. We collected a large multimodal dataset of more than 180 participants engaging in a complex learning activity from multiple texts on scientific research methods. The data included fNIRS, EEG, eye tracking, galvanic skin response (GSR), optical pulse/PPG (photoplethysmography), video, reading time, mind wandering, comprehension assessments, and individual difference measures.
  • Language localizers in more ecological contexts. We identified functional language regions in individual brains using fNIRS collected during a language localizer task and ascertained the overlap between regions identified with fNIRS and fMRI, validating the use of fNIRS for less-invasive studies of brain mechanisms that support reading. 
  • Eye-gaze models of reading comprehension. We built and validated gaze-based computational models of reading comprehension at various depths (surface, rote, inference, integration, transfer) and across time (during, after, delay) to advance basic research on the eye-mind link during reading. 
  • Eye-brain link. We explored how eye movements and brain activations (with fNIRS) relate during reading. Specifically, we developed a measure of the alignment between select eye and brain features and examined how this eye-brain alignment varied across different cognitive states, thereby putting the brain into the well-established eye-mind link. 
  • Self-supervised representation learning of eye-gaze during reading. We developed deep learning architectures to learn a neural representation of eye gaze data by introducing a self-supervised model for scan path prediction that captures spatial (x, y) and temporal (t) gaze patterns over text. The model generates gaze embeddings, which are used as input for downstream tasks across a range of applications 

 

We disseminated our findings in 26 peer-reviewed publications as well as in book chapters, non-archival conference presentations, invited keynotes, and invited talks/panels.

 

Intellectual Merit

Blending basic neurobehavioral research with computational modeling, the research yielded foundational theoretical, methodological, and technological advances.

  • From a theoretical perspective, we advanced our understanding of eye-brain-mind links by integrating three research areas: theories of low-level reading processes and associated models of eye movements, models of higher-order text comprehension including multiple document comprehension, and emerging research on the cognitive neuroscience of reading including co-registration with eye movements.
  • Methodologically, the project demonstrated the feasibility of collecting high-fidelity neurophysiological measures (fNIRS, EEG, eye tracking, and peripheral physiology) in more ecological settings (i.e., outside of the scanner), while also contributing a multimodal dataset for future research. It introduced eye-brain alignment as a novel approach to integrate brain and behavioral signals to examine the eye-mind link more deeply.
  • For a technological perspective, our novel self-supervised representational deep learning model of eye gaze achieved state-of-the-art results in modeling reading behaviors with embeddings that can be potentially used in various downstream tasks.

 

Broader Impacts

  • With respect to interdisciplinary training, the project has supported training of more than 15 postdocs, graduate students, several undergraduate students, and research staff. Personnel were trained in the interdisciplinary fields of discourse processing, eye tracking, neuroscience, and machine learning.
  • With respect to broadening participation of underrepresented groups in science, the project supported the PhD research of one female computer science student and the postdoctoral training of four women scientists.
  • Longer term broader impacts include improving literacy outcomes in U.S. students by advancing the science of reading and complex learning from texts.
  • The focus on promoting critical thinking and scientific reasoning skills has important societal implications especially in the age of generative AI.
